sols_html:
First, using Heron’s formula, we have that the semiperimeter is \(\displaystyle s = 1\) and so

\(\displaystyle A^{2} = (1-a)(1-a)(1-b)\).

Next, the perimeter is given by \(\displaystyle 2 = 2a + b\) and so \(\displaystyle b = 2-2a\). Substituting this into the area formula, we have

\(\displaystyle A^{2} = (1-a)^{2}(1-(2-2a)) = (1-a)^{2}(2a-1)\)

Taking the derivative implicitly with respect to a via the chain rule and product rule, we have

\[\begin{aligned} 2AA' &= (2(1-a)(-1))(2a-1) + (1-a)^{2}(2) \\ &= -2(1-a)(2a-1) + 2(1-a)^{2} \\ &= 2(1-a)(-(2a-1) + (1-a)) \\ &= -2(1-a)(3a-2) \end{aligned}\]

Setting the derivative to 0 and optimizing gives a=1 and a = 2/3. Now, looking at the Perimeter restraint

\(\displaystyle 2 = 2a + b\)

We see that the maximum either occurs at the end points or when a=2/3.

To find the endpoints we consider degenerating the triangle into a straight line. We get a vertical straight line when \(b=0\). In this case \(2=2a+b\) yields \(a=1\). Similarly, we get a horizontal straight line when \(b\) is as large as possible, which is when \(b=2a\). In this case \(2=2a+b\) yields \(2=2a+2a\) and hence \(a=1/2\).

At the endpoints, the area of the triangle is 0 and so at the maximum will be at \(a=2/3\). Thus,

\(\displaystyle A(2/3) = \sqrt{(1-(2/3))^{2}(2(2/3)-1)} = \sqrt{(1/9)(1/3)} = \frac{1}{3\sqrt{3}}\)

completing the proof.

statement_html:
Consider the isosceles triangle given in the following figure, where a and b indicate the side lengths. Assume that the triangle has a circumference of 2. Find the lengths a and b for which the area A of the triangle is maximized. You must also check that you found a maximum and your solution must include that check. Hint: Heron’s formula may be useful which states that

\[\begin{aligned} A^{2} = s(s - x)(s - y)(s - z)\end{aligned}\]

where A is the area of the triangle, x, y, z are its side lengths and s = (x+y+z)/2.
